page.title: 04HEATHLAND cont.
page.content: A different type of oak is also found, its leaves have a sharper curve. This is called the Turkey oak. Different vegetation includes cotton grass,sun- dews,nettles and a general ground cov- ering of moss.The same animals are found with additions of small frogs & toads.The soil is mainly peat and less prone to fire. Butterflies & moths are found in both areas.Birds found include thrushes,starlings,sparrows, stonechats,woodpeckers and nightjars. The heathland has been extensively planted with conifers since the end of 18th.century.100 years later a royal physician declared the area an except- ionally healthy one.Now conifers,mil- itary activity and housing compete for the infertile soils.It is a contrast to the 18th.century when highwaymen rode a heath later described by Cobbett as"bleak,barren & villanous".
